posts.title: Getting Ready for Kindergarten
posts.text: To better prepare your little one for this big moment, take a look at the books and digital resources we have available.

posts.title: Reconstructing 1940s Dances of Sophie Maslow and Pearl Primus from the Archives
posts.text: How do archival materials help researchers piece together impressions of historical performances? A guest post by Jessica Friedman, 2019 NYPL Short-term Research Fellow with the Jerome Robbins Dance Division.

posts.title: Ethan Hawke: Do people really still use libraries?
posts.text: Just last night, my 16-year-old son asked me, "Do people really still use libraries?" I was happy to be able to tell him yes. It's a fact: More people than ever are visiting their neighborhood branches and using the myriad free resources the Library provides.The public library is a more vital community center than ever before.

posts.title: Ronald Clark Shares Stories and Photos of Living Inside a Branch of The New York Public Library
posts.text: When the Library's branches were heated by coal, many had a custodian who lived inside the branch, often with family, to keep the building warm. Raymond Clark, custodian for over three decades, lived at NYPL's Washington Heights Library with his son Ronald and granddaughter Jamilah.

posts.title: Researcher Spotlight: Chana Pollack
posts.text: Pollack has been the 'Forward's' archivist for the past two decades, providing research, translation, and production of original archival content with an eye on the contemporary context.

posts.title: Celebrating Jewish LGBT Pride
posts.text: In honor of Pride Month in June, the Dorot Jewish Division recognizes the achievements of LGBT Jews in history and in the Library’s collection. Here are some key moments and figures.

posts.title: Getting Started with Holocaust Genealogy Research
posts.text: There are many personal and practical reasons for undertaking genealogical research in connection with the Holocaust. In honor of International Holocaust Remembrance Day on January 27, we've compiled a wealth of resources to help you get started.

posts.title: NYPL Researcher Spotlight: Ariel Paige Cohen
posts.text: She tells us about researching her forthcoming book and how she's fared doing research from home during the pandemic.

posts.title: In Other Words: Yiddish Women in Translation Month
posts.text: It is astounding both how many women have written in Yiddish, and how thoroughly they have been marginalized.

posts.title: Immigrant Heritage Month: Explore Ladino Online
posts.text: Learn more about the language and preservation efforts.

posts.title: Unorthodox Reading Companions: Going Off the Derech with Quarantine's Hottest Show
posts.text: Explore more of this powerful, emerging literary genre.

posts.title: Exploring Ethnic NewsWatch
posts.text: It's a terrific resource—particularly for hard-to-find, small local publications as well as academic journals for which physical copies are not easily accessible.

posts.title: Free Online Language Learning Resources for Kids
posts.text: Childhood is an ideal time to learn a new language.

posts.title: Fordham-NYPL Research Fellows in Jewish Studies, 2019-2020
posts.text: Meet three fellows joining the Library, and check out their lines of study and research relevant to Jewish studies and history.

posts.title: Yizkor Books at The New York Public Library
posts.text: Yizkor ("memorial") books are an important primary source documenting the history of Jewish communities destroyed during the Holocaust. The 700 yizkor books at the NYPL make up the largest collection of its kind in North American, and the most heavily used. See how researchers and genealogists use these vital records, and how you can access yizkor books digitally, for free.

posts.title: Yiddish Drama Queen: Jennie Goldstein in Pictures
posts.text: On the anniversary of her death, here is our illustrated tribute to Jennie Goldstein, the woman whose long and varied career spanned the Yiddish stage, theatre ownership, film, and beyond.

posts.title: Introducing the 2018-2019 Fordham University NYPL Research Fellows in Jewish Studies
posts.text: Here are five scholars from Israel, Europe, and the United States, who are coming to New York to pursue their Jewish studies research projects and share their work with the public.

posts.title: Inaugural Class: Fordham-NYPL Research Fellows in Jewish Studies
posts.text: Congratulations to the inaugural class of Fordham-NYPL Research Fellows in Jewish Studies! This joint pilot fellowship program is for scholars in all fields of Jewish Studies from outside the New York City metropolitan area.

posts.title: Honoring LGBT Jewish Holocaust Survivors
posts.text: This LGBT Pride Month, the Dorot Jewish Division honors the lives and work of LGBT Jewish Holocaust survivors. We’ve compiled short biographies of several individuals, with links to related publications and online resources.

posts.title: The Dorot Jewish Division Invites You: Fall Events
posts.text: The Dorot Jewish Division of The New York Public Library, one of the world's great collections of Hebraica and Judaica, invites you to join us for the upcoming events this fall.

posts.title: A Happy, Healthy, Gluten-Free New Year
posts.text: September is an opportune time to try some festive gluten-free recipes: it is when Food Allergy Awareness Month coincides with the Jewish month of Elul, which culminates with Rosh Hashanah (the Jewish New Year) on the eve of October 2.

posts.title: Women in Translation Month: Yiddish
posts.text: August is Women in Translation Month. Celebrate Yiddish women writers in English translation with poetry, fiction, memoirs, prayers, and cookbooks from the Library’s collection.

posts.title: Passover Resources, from the Rose Family Seder Books to the Seder Plate
posts.text: From the beautiful Rose Family Seder Books to preparing a seder plate, the Library has something for everyone.

posts.title: Celebrating African American Jews
posts.text:
In honor of African American History Month, the Dorot Jewish Division celebrates African American Jewish authors and achievements.
Updated May 21, 2020.

posts.title: Voices of Holocaust Survivors: Oral Histories and Personal Narratives
posts.text: Survivors’ personal stories are a powerful primary source for learning about the Holocaust. Explore the Library’s collection of oral histories, autobiographies, biographies and memoirs of Holocaust survivors.

posts.title: Landsmanshaftn in New York: A Quick Online Guide
posts.text: Landsmanshaftn are Jewish community organizations of immigrants from the same city in Eastern or Central Europe. Their documents provide important information for genealogical research.

posts.title: Celebrating Transgender Jews: 2020 Edition
posts.text: Read inspiring life stories by and about transgender Jews, and find scholarly and community resources on gender identity and Judaism.

posts.title: Yiddish Theater Research: A Quick Online Guide
posts.text: General works, plays, biography, images, and archives pertaining to Yiddish Theater.

posts.title: Jewish Genealogy: A Quick Online Guide
posts.text: Find out how to get information about your Jewish roots. Links to vital records, Holocaust resources, name origins, and Jewish genealogy collections.

posts.title: Finding Yiddish Music: A Quick Online Guide
People of the (Online) Book: Jewish Texts Online
posts.text: Here’s a brief guide to Jewish books online, including reference works, religious texts and literature.

posts.title: A Quick Guide to Jewish Periodicals
posts.text: Where to find periodicals online, in microfim, and in print, compiled by the Dorot Jewish Division.

posts.title: Matzah and Melodrama: Nahum Stutchkoff's Yiddish Song Lyrics
posts.text: Nahum Stutchkoff (1893-1965) was a beloved Yiddish radio personality, playwright, lyricist and linguist who created dramas and commercials for WEVD radio and compiled a Yiddish rhyming dictionary and thesaurus. Once a household name among New York Yiddish speakers, he even appeared in ads for Beech-Nut Gum, Seagram’s Whiskey, and Planter’s High Hat Peanut Oil.

posts.title: Yiddish Theater Posters of the 1890s
posts.text: Our Digital Collection includes Yiddish theater posters dating back more than a hundred years. These ephemeral pieces, with their bold titles, portraits of actors, and exuberant descriptions of plays, illustrate the dynamic Yiddish theater tradition.

posts.title: The Yiddish Broadway and Beyond
posts.text: Given New York City’s major role in the Yiddish theater, it’s no surprise that The New York Public Library has a wonderful Yiddish theater collection. Here you’ll find posters, playbills, sheet music, published plays, photographs, manuscripts, memoirs, oral histories and recordings that tell the story of Yiddish theater and its legendary stars.

posts.title: 2018: The Year in Archival Research
posts.text: Here are a dozen recent books whose authors relied on the Library's archival records as a vital resource, from the world of George Washington to the history of the Manhattan waterfront. Add these to your 2019 reading list!

posts.title: The Story Behind The Library's Copy of Thomas Jefferson's Declaration of Independence
posts.text: The New York Public Library holds in its vast collections one of the most important documents in American history: an original manuscript of the Declaration of Independence handwritten by Thomas Jefferson.

posts.title: A Melville Marginalia Mystery
posts.text: A researcher's reading of erased marginalia provides insight to Melville's thoughts on religion.

posts.title: The Nican Mopohua and Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe
posts.text: Among the many treasures of the New York Public Library are documents created as the New World was explored and settled by Europeans and a hybrid culture emerged. James Lenox (1880-1880) whose books, manuscripts, and maps formed the great base for the Library's collection was interested in the history of the Americas. This blog post focuses on a set of documents long referred to as the Monumentos Guadalupanos, or Guadeloupean Monuments, and one document in particular, the Nican Mopohua. A facsimile edition of this historic manuscript is currently underway from SYL Creaciones Graficas and

posts.title: Focus On: Recent Acquisitions in the Manuscripts Division
A Closer Look at Jefferson's Declaration
posts.text: In the days immediately following its ratification on July 4, 1776, Jefferson made copies of the Declaration that had been submitted to the Continental Congress and underlined those passages to which changes had been made. This blog post will summarize the history of Jefferson's draft of the Declaration of Independence and describe how it came to be a part of the Library’s collection.

posts.title: 2012-2013 Short-Term Research Fellowship Recipients Announced
Symphony of the New World: 50th Anniversary of a Pioneering Organization
posts.text: In May 1964, two months before The Civil Rights Act (outlawing discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin) became law, noted conductor Benjamin Steinberg formed a committee of 13 musicians, 12 of whom were African American, with the intention of forming a new integrated orchestra called the Symphony of the New World (SNW).

posts.title: Join NYPL at the 2018 American Library Association Conference
posts.text: If you're heading to New Orleans for ALAAC18 in late June, check out these programs featuring NYPL staff, including a panel with NYPL President Tony Marx discussing fines as a barrier to access.

posts.title: Creative Aging in Our Communities
Josephine Baker: Entertainer and Activist
posts.text: As one of the most admired performers of the 20th century, Josephine made full use of her celebrity status to bravely call attention to discriminatory racial practices in the United States and Europe.

posts.title: Looking Back at Fiscal Year 2020 at The Library for the Performing Arts
posts.text: You're invited to look through our Annual Report and celebrate with us some of the things we accomplished this past year.

posts.title: Srimathi Gina: A Life Devoted to Indian Classical Dance
The Mythology of Bruno Schulz
posts.text: How did a Jewish writer, who wrote exclusively in Polish and who died in the Holocaust, become practically a cult figure of mid-­20th century literature?

posts.title: Stefan Zweig's New Life
posts.text: Stefan Zweig is experiencing a major comeback in the English-speaking world. The works of fiction of this Austrian Jewish writer (1881-1942) are being reissued in new translations, including his novels such as Beware of Pity and The Post-Office Girl; and director Wes Anderson says that his delightful new film, Grand Budapest Hotel, was "inspired" by Zweig's writings. And now a new biography, by George Prochnik, is appearing: The Impossible Exile: Stefan Zweig at the End of the World.

posts.title: 2022 Library Resolutions
posts.text: Resolutions to help you live your best library life!

posts.title: A Literary Potluck: Holiday Recipe Recommendations from Berg Staff
posts.text: Drawing on some of the Berg's foremost authors' archives, this list has something for everyone whether you're an experienced chef or still getting your bearings in the kitchen.

posts.title: Researcher Spotlight: Megan Brown
posts.text: "My research projects have all wound up in places that are vastly different from where I started out. Be open to following your source’s lead."

posts.title: Reopening Dates for Five NYPL Branches Formerly In Use by the City
posts.text: Riverdale, St. Agnes, Dongan Hills, Mariners Harbor, and Hamilton Grange libraries—in use by the city as Learning Labs or COVID testing sites—are set to reopen between July 26 and August 9.

posts.title: NYPL and City Partner to Host Mobile Community Vaccine Clinics at Local Branches
posts.text: The mobile units will be parked in high needs communities at select NYPL libraries to provide Pfizer vaccines to the neighborhood.

posts.title: It's Poetry Month: Here Are NYPL's Best Poetry Books of 2020
posts.text: Friendship, race, motherhood, nature, womanhood, trauma, identity: these topics and many more are explored within the pages of our staff's favorite poetry books of last year.

posts.text: Vote daily for your favorites and keep watching to see who will reign supreme!

posts.text: With recommendations for kids, teens and adults, these books—all written in the last few years—by Jewish authors reflect the diversity of the Jewish faith and experience.

posts.title: Honoring Eric Jerome Dickey
posts.text: Eric Jerome Dickey was a true titan in the realm of African American Literature. For many of our librarians and patrons, his books were some of the first ones they discovered as young adults that actually spoke to their lived experience.

posts.title: Make These Library Resolutions in 2021!
posts.text: Make the New York Public Library a bigger part of your 2021. We have so much to offer!

posts.title: Spend the Holidays at the Library (On Your Video Calls At Least!)

posts.title: Researcher Spotlight: Preeti Sodhi

posts.title: Happy Diwali from The New York Public Library
posts.text: Diwali, which means array of lamps, started when the people of Ayodhya lit diyas inside and outside their homes to celebrate Lord Rama’s triumphant return and also good over evil.

posts.title: Horrorscopes! Tell Us Your Sign & We'll Tell You What Scary Book to Read

posts.title: Grab & Goサービスの利用方法
posts.text: 図書館の利用者の皆様は、実際の本やビデオを図書館の蔵書コレクションから借りられるのを心待ちにしていらっしゃることと思います。そこでまず、いくつかの分館にて限られたサービスを行い、図書館再開のための段階的なプロセスを慎重に進めていくことを決定しました。7月13日（月）より、選考された分館でGrab & Goサービスを行っています。

posts.title: Как воспользоваться сервисом «Возьми с собой на дом»
posts.text: Мы также прекрасно понимаем, что несмотря на все новшества, наши читатели с нетерпением  дожидаются момента когда вновь можно будет взять книги на дом. Ввиду этого, Библиотека, принимая все меры предосторожности,  проводит поэтапный процесс возобновления ограниченной деятельности своих филиалов.

posts.text: I presented at the Computers in Libraries conference in Arlington, Virginia this past March, and between sessions I decided to find out what people were reading.

posts.title: What Are You Reading: John Bloom/Joe Bob Briggs Edition
posts.text: Find out what John Bloom AKA Joe Bob Briggs is reading, his research and writing process, and more!

posts.title: What Are You Reading? Powerpuff Girls Edition
posts.text: I attended the Powerpuff Girls Panel at this year's New York Comic Con, and scored an interview with two of the show's writers: Jake Goldman and Haley Mancini.

posts.title: What Are You Reading? Jeannine Otis Edition
posts.text: Otis is a recording artist, actress, author, teaching artist, and more. There's not a lot in the entertainment industry she hasn't done, and done well. She shares which books have most influenced her life, and as a survivor of domestic violence, what books she'd recommend to someone struggling to overcome trauma.

posts.title: What Are You Reading? Paula Poundstone Edition
posts.text: A master of crowd-work, Poundstone’s shows are different every night. Her improvisational style works well for her, not only onstage but as a regular on the NPR show “Wait Wait… Don’t Tell Me!” She has been a major supporter of libraries throughout the years and  is a national spokesperson for the American Library Association’s United for Libraries division. We asked her a few questions about her reading habits.

posts.title: What Are You Reading? Lemony Snicket Edition
posts.text: Handler attends the American Library Association Conference each year, promoting literacy and library excellence through his Lemony Snicket Prize for Noble Librarians Faced with Adversity award. The book signing gave me the opportunity to ask him a few questions.

posts.title: What Are You Reading? Ratso Edition
posts.text: The author Larry “Ratso” Sloman answers a few questions about reading and libraries.

posts.title: What Are You Reading? Colum McCann Edition
posts.text: Colum McCann visited the library as part of our staff-wide read, so I caught up with him to see if he had other reading recommendations.

posts.title: Happy National Popcorn Day!
posts.text: January 19 is National Popcorn Day! Celebrate with these recipes ranging from the basic to the advanced.

posts.title: Mid-Manhattan Cookie Lit
posts.text: What's better than curling up with a good book? Curling up with a good book and some book related cookies! In honor of National Cookie Day, the staff at Mid-Manhattan Library put together some deliciously literate cookies for your enjoyment!

posts.title: What Are You Reading? Carlos Alazraqui Edition
posts.text: Find out what the Rocko's Modern Life and Reno 911 star likes to read.

posts.title: What Are You Reading? Harlem Globetrotters Edition
posts.text: I caught up with a few of the Harlem Globetrotters while they were on a shoot at the William F. Passannante Ballfield in the West Village. A nearby elementary school uses the park as a playground during school hours, and the Globetrotters mingled with the kids, juggling balls and answering questions between takes.

posts.title: The Blacklist: What is Red Reading?
posts.text: Passing through Bryant Park on the way to work recently, I came upon a shoot for the upcoming season of The Blacklist and decided to find out what Reddington himself was currently reading.

posts.title: Announcing the 2021 Young Lions Fiction Award Finalists
posts.text: We are pleased to announce the finalists for the twenty-first annual Young Lions Fiction Award, honoring the works of five talented young authors.

posts.title: Announcing the 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award Finalists
posts.text: We are pleased to announce the finalists for the twentieth annual Young Lions Fiction Award, honoring the works of five talented young authors.

posts.title: Announcing the 2019 Young Lions Fiction Award Finalists
posts.text: We are pleased to announce the finalists for the nineteenth annual Young Lions Fiction Award, honoring the works of five talented young authors.

posts.title: NYPL 2019 Make Music New York Lineup
posts.text: Celebrate the summer solstice with a series of performances at multiple Library locations, Friday, June 21, all part of the 2019 Make Music New York. Check out this year's lineup!

posts.title: Crafting the Collections
posts.text: Discover the work of artist / photographer Anna Atkins and create your own beautiful art, with this brand-new initiative coming to NYPL locations.

posts.title: Reimagine End of Life Festival Listings
posts.text: During this one-week exploration of death and celebration of life, the Library will hold events across the city from October 27 through November 3.

posts.title: Favorite Trans, Nonbinary, and GNC Titles of 2020
posts.text: It might have been a roller coaster of a year but there was still time to enjoy new books. This list includes books for children, teens and adults.

posts.title: 40 Animal E-Books for Kids of All Ages
posts.text: Birds, mammals, fish and more—these books can help kids learn more about their favorite animal or find a new favorite!

posts.title: Black Lives Black Motorists
posts.text: Within our contemporary climate of #BlackLivesMatter, The Green Book guides deserve continued discussion of their value as not only a practical travel resource for their time, but also as a survival guide.

posts.title: Joy Out of Fire: Ethel Waters
posts.text: Learn about entertainment pioneer, Ethel Waters, in a blog inspired by the Schomburg Center's Firelei BáezJoy Out of Fire exhibition.

posts.title: Joy Out of Fire: Josephine Baker
posts.text: This post is the first in the "Joy Out of Fire" series on expressions of femininity reclaimed by 20th century Black women entertainers inspired by "Firelei Baez: Joy Out of Fire"  currently on display in the Latimer/Edison Gallery at the Schomburg Center.

posts.title: The Time to Build is Upon Us: How Nelson Mandela’s Words Resonate With Us Today
posts.text: Learn more about Nelson Mandela’s life and legacy through items in the Schomburg's Collections.

posts.title: Remembering John Coltrane
posts.text: On July 17, we commemorate 51 years since the death of American jazz composer and saxophonist John Coltrane who passed away in 1967.

posts.title: The Way to Right Wrongs: Celebrating the Legacy of Ida B. Wells
posts.text: Celebrate Ida B. Wells, co-founder of the NAACP, journalist, educator and truth seeker, and the legacy she left behind within the Civil Rights movement.

posts.title: Schomburg Center Celebrates Reopening of Renovated Spaces
NYPL’s Maud Malone: Radical Feminist, Union Leader, Equal Pay Advocate
posts.text: Maud Malone is known by history as a radical suffragist, but her work at the Library had its own activist bent.

posts.title: Home Confinement: A Peculiarly Suitable Setting for Engaging with Women’s History
posts.text: After all, women were largely confined to the domestic sphere not for mere months, but for centuries.

posts.title: Masks Are the New Mittens
posts.text: The long tradition of private efforts to protect the public’s health.

posts.title: April Fooling With Suffragists a Century Ago—And How to Find Out if Your Ancestors Were Involved With the Suffrage Movement
posts.text: Many of the resources you'll need are available online, so you don’t have to wait to get started.

posts.title: Books to Celebrate Women's Equality Day
posts.text: On August 26, 1920, the 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution became official. On paper, every American woman had the right to vote.

posts.title: Genealogy Tips: Using NYPL Resources at Home to Research Immigrant Ancestors
posts.text: Visiting New York City and want to look for records of your ancestors at The NYPL? With these fantastic online resources, you can start your research at home and continue after your trip - so, after your Library visit, you can spend more time seeing more our city!

posts.title: Genealogy How-To Books: How a Little Reading Can Save You A Lot Of Time
posts.text: Looking for your family history? Wanting to find your ancestors? Consulting a genealogy research guide will almost certainly save you time, effort, and frustration. Check out our recommended how-to books and references, and start finding what you're looking for.

posts.title: Genealogy Tips: Getting Down to (Family) Business
posts.text: With these tips and our new research guide, you can search for information about your ancestors' business and careers, to get a better understanding of their past and your family.

posts.title: Published Family Histories: An Under-Tapped Resource
posts.text: When used wisely, family histories lend incredible color and context to the past for any budding genealogist.

posts.title: Library Zine! Voices from Across The New York Public Library
posts.text: Explore selections from the first issue of Library Zine!—a creative writing magazine containing original writing and visual art submitted by library patrons and staff of all ages.

posts.title: Announcing the Winner of the 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award
posts.text: The New York Public Library is proud to announce that Bryan Washington has won the twentieth annual Young Lions Fiction Award for his book 'Lot'.

posts.title: What Andy Borowitz Is Reading
posts.text: Six comic novels to lift your spirits.

posts.title: What Min Jin Lee Is Reading
posts.text: Check out this recommended reading list from the bestselling author of 'Free Food for Millionaires' and 'Pachinko'.

posts.title: A Wish for the New Year
posts.text: Sting shares a wish for the New Year.

posts.title: Announcing the Andrew Heiskell Library Podcast: "Talkin' Talking Books"
posts.text: We have a beautiful, hilarious, and touching group of people who make this world of talking books turn, and we want to connect with you all.

posts.title: It's a Great Year to Read Harder: Book Riot's 2022 Challenge
posts.text: Even the most prolific readers often tread the same literary stomping grounds. Branch out and try new genres and new authors this year!

posts.title: Here Are 2021's Top Checkouts by Borough
posts.text: Find out which books were the most popular checkouts this year in each NYC borough.

posts.title: COVID-19 Vaccines for 5-11 Year Olds to be Offered at Select NYPL Branches Beginning on December 18
posts.text: Eight branches of The New York Public Library will offer COVID-19 vaccinations for 5–11 year olds beginning on Saturday, December 18, 2021.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: A Midsummer Book Lover's Dream
posts.text: Explore some of the hottest new reads recommended by our expert librarians—plus, find everything the Library has to offer now that we've fully reopened.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: The Library Is Back—and Here for You!
posts.text: All available branches are now open and offering nearly full service. See you at the Library!

posts.title: NYPL Events: What's Happening 7/5–18
posts.text: Join us in Bryant Park for discussions about American History, discover a new writing workshop for immigrant writers, and test your film trivia skills.

posts.title: NYPL Remembers Activist Kay Lahusen
posts.text: The New York Public Library is saddened to hear about the passing of Katherine "Kay" Lahusen, whose activism, photography, and writing helped to bring LGBTQ+ rights to the forefront of society, shining a light on the vibrant and fulfilling lives of lesbians and highlighting queer subcultures.

posts.title: Celebrating Haiti: Books by Haitian & Haitian American Authors
posts.text: Novels for adults and young adults, stories, poetry, and anthologies, these works offer a textured and diverse look at the resiliency and vibrancy of this nation and its people.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Computer Reservations & Browsing Now Available at Select Locations
posts.text: Find out about expanded access to onsite services, plus get ready for Ranked Choice Voting with our Big Apple Book Ballot!

posts.title: Video: Libraries Make NYC Stronger
posts.text: Take 30 seconds to remind City leaders that funding libraries is key to helping NYC come back strong. Sign a letter and stand with your library.

posts.title: NYPL Events: What's Happening 5/9–5/23
posts.text: Celebrate Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month, plus sign up for a talk with Anna Sale and Michael Arceneaux, and go behind the scenes with Broadway prop masters.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Celebrating Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month
posts.text: Find free online events, book recommendations for all ages, and special storytimes to celebrate Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month!

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Starting Today! NYPL's First-Ever World Literature Festival
posts.text: Discover the full event lineup, find top checkouts in 21 languages, and explore our free resources in Español, 中文, Русский, বাংলা, Français, 日本語, and more for all ages!

posts.title: NYPL Events: What's Happening 4/11–4/25
posts.text: Discover talks featuring Louis Menand with A.O. Scott, Kaitlyn Greenidge with Edwidge Danticat, and Joshua Jelly-Schapiro with Suketu Mehta, plus sign up for NYPL's first-ever World Literature Festival.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Spring into reading with Poetry Month and new Staff Picks
posts.text: Start reading Kazuo Ishiguro's latest novel as part of April's Get Lit book club—plus, register now for our first-ever World Literature Festival!

posts.title: NYPL Events: What's Happening 3/15–3/28
posts.text: Ethan Hawke on his first novel in 20 years, plus Vivian Gornick looks back on her career as a beloved critic, a discussion on criminal justice reform, and the Women's Jazz Festival returns.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Libraries Make NYC Stronger
posts.text: From books and information to programs and other free resources—NYPL is here for you.

posts.title: NYPL Events: What's Happening 3/1–3/14
posts.text: Elizabeth Kolbert explores the science of saving the future, plus learn about the most famous woman American artist you’ve never heard of—and more!

posts.title: NYPL Connect: New Online Exhibition, Exciting Author Talks & Your Next Read!
posts.text: Celebrate Black History Month, Lunar New Year, and the magic of NYC with book events, reading lists, and family programs.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Celebrate Black History Month with Ibram X. Kendi, Keisha N. Blain, Hilton Als, Charles Blow, Heather McGhee, Michelle Commander & More
posts.text: Explore new book lists highlighting Black history, plus find online events for kids, teens, and adults.

posts.title: NYPL Events: Spend a Year Abroad with Chang-rae Lee and Paul Yoon, Plus Ibram X. Kendi Explores the Makings of a Communal History and More Black History Month Events
posts.text: Coming up: Unearthing new stories from the Civil Rights Movement, Alyssa Cole finds love in a hopeless place, and NYPL archivists reveal what's new in our archives.

posts.title: 10 Tips for Reading Aloud with Children
posts.text: Making reading a pleasurable habit is one of the most important things you can do for a child to set them up for lifelong readership. To celebrate World Read Aloud Day, our librarians are sharing some of their best advice for reading aloud with children.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: A Time for Discussion, Unity & Healing
posts.text: A message from NYPL President Tony Marx, plus conversations with Jiayang Fan, Gina Belafonte, Martha S. Jones, Rashad Robinson, Valarie Kaur, Amber Ruffin, and more.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Start a New Chapter with the Library in 2021
posts.text: Discover Story Line, our new dial-a-story service, attend the Schomburg's 2021 Black Comic Book Festival virtually, download January's Get Lit book club pick, and more!

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Our Top Checkouts of 2020 Are In! Find Out What New Yorkers Read Most This Year
posts.text: Find out if you read the most checked out books of the year, plus chat with Jonathan Lethem, author of our December book club pick, and get in the spirit with our Holiday Open House.

posts.title: Jerome Robbins Dance Division Acquires Remy Charlip's Collection
posts.text: The Jerome Robbins Dance Division was honored to acquire the Remy Charlip Collection in 2020.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Say Goodbye to 2020 with Desus & Mero, Molly Crabapple, Hari Kunzru, Nikki Giovanni, Aparna Nancherla, Aminatou Sow, Rebecca Traister, and More
posts.text: Hear from award-winning authors, plus find job search help, a new online exhibition about The Nutcracker, and more free resources for all ages.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: New Book List, All About New York! 125 NYC Books We Love
posts.text: Desus and Mero, Molly Crabapple, Isaac Fitzgerald, and more help us explore the magic of New York City!

posts.title: Agree to Disagree: A New York State of Mind
posts.text: We might disagree on pretty much everything, but we all love NYC.

posts.title: NYPL Connect: NYPL's Best Books of 2020 List Just Released!
posts.text: Find out if your favorite books made the list, join conversations with Best Books authors, and ask Louise Erdrich about her work—only at the Library.

posts.title: Public Art Comes to Stavros Niarchos Foundation Library
posts.text: The New York Public Library is working on a temporary art project at the new Stavros Niarchos Foundation Library with the Soho Renaissance Factory, a collective of artists who “make art for the public good.”

posts.title: NYPL Connect: Indigenous Peoples' Day Reading List, Election Issues, and Online Events for All Ages
posts.text: Tonight! Women at the Forefront of Climate Justice—plus, check out discussions with Jamelle Bouie, Laila Lalami, and more.

posts.title: Books We Love: NYPL Librarians on WNET!
posts.text: What unites them is the deep feelings they inspire—they’ll make kids laugh, connect, and want to learn more.

posts.title: Lighting Up the Empire State Building for NYPL's 125th Anniversary
posts.text: Our iconic red hue was on display around the city.

posts.title: Anniversary Video: Reading Brings Us Together
posts.text: We asked 125 people to tell us about a book they loved. Here's what they had to say—and how you can join in.

posts.title: Missing Sounds of New York: An Auditory Love Letter to New Yorkers
posts.text: Not so quiet, please, New York! We made an album called “Missing Sounds of New York” to bring the noise we miss back into our city.

posts.title: Which Literary House Would You Call Home?
posts.text: These housemates are real characters.

posts.title: If the Parks & Rec Crew Loved the Library: A Reading List
posts.text: You might think after the vitriol they've spewed at libraries we wouldn't waste our time finding them the perfect reading recommendations. You'd be wrong—it's the Library way.

posts.title: Join NYPL's #BookCoverDouble Challenge!
posts.text: Whether you are staying home alone, with family, friends, roommates or furry friends, we hope you'll join us and recreate a book cover you love.

posts.title: What New Yorkers Are Reading Right Now
posts.text: Inspiring biographies, dystopian novels, book clubs, and boy wizards are helping New Yorkers cope with our current moment.

posts.title: Our Research Librarians Share Some of Their Favorite Online Resources (That You Can Use at Home)
posts.text: Online platforms they refer to over and over again.

posts.title: You're Not Alone: Mental Health Reads
posts.text: Great books remind us that we’re not alone in challenging times.

posts.title: Where to Find Up-to-Date Information on Coronavirus (COVID-19) for New York City Residents
posts.text: Resources to help you stay informed.

posts.title: All the Reasons to #LoveReading
posts.text: From unearthing favorite childhood memories to looming lists of the best books you've ever read, here are some of our favorite responses to the question: What book made you #LoveReading?

posts.title: Neil Gaiman: What Book Made You #LoveReading?
posts.text: "The thing that gets people reading is love."

posts.title: Interview: Kristin O'Donnell Tubb Returns With a New Library Mystery
posts.text: Author Kristin O'Donnell Tubb tells us about the latest literary adventure of (real life) NYPL library resident Viviani Fedeler.

posts.title: We're Celebrating 125 Years and Our Top 10 Checkouts of All Time
posts.text: To mark this milestone year we've compiled a list of our 10 most borrowed books—ever—as well as the release of limited-edition library cards and MetroCards.

posts.title: Patron Picks: "The Gift of Reading" at Open Book Hour
posts.text: From picture books to novels and cookbooks, take a look at patrons' favorite books to give as gifts.

posts.title: Are You "Reading Harder" in 2020? We've Got You.
posts.text: Are you joining Book Riot in their "Read Harder" challenge this year? If so, we've got suggestions in all 24 categories—all available at the library!

posts.title: Patron Picks: Things That Go Bump in the Night at Open Book Hour
posts.text: Peek at the spooky picks from our last Open Book Hour at Mid-Manhattan Library, from the Monstress collection and Walking Dead comic novels to Stephen King and Agatha Christie.

posts.title: Remembering Jessye Norman
posts.text: Iconic opera singer, activist, and a beloved member of the Library family, Jessye Norman passed away on September 30, 2019, at age 74.

posts.title: Where to Start with Zora Neale Hurston
posts.text: With her extensive knowledge of Black folklore, culture, and hoodoo, Zora Neale Hurston crafted literature that offered unprecedented anecdotes of the Black experience in the African Diaspora.

posts.title: Meet Brian Bannon, Merryl and James Tisch Director
posts.text: Brian Bannon is The New York Public Library's first-ever Merryl and James Tisch Director.

posts.title: The Library Shines Bright in Times Square
posts.text: This September, The New York Public Library is partnering with Morgan Stanley to put the spotlight on reading in Times Square.

posts.title: The New York Public Library Honors the Life of Toni Morrison
posts.text: The Library is saddened by the loss of Toni Morrison, author, and New York Public Library Lifetime Trustee.

posts.title: Sunday Service Added for July 21 to Help New Yorkers Beat the Heat
posts.text: With New York City temperatures expected to hover around 100 degrees this weekend, The New York Public Library has decided to open five additional branches on Sunday, July 21 to help New Yorkers stay cool and safe.

posts.title: NYPL Bookmobile Starts Service in the Bronx
posts.text: The New York Public Library Bookmobile is on the move.

posts.title: Video: Libraries Make NYC Stronger
posts.text: This morning, the City Council met to discuss next year's budget for libraries. Our staff shared this video with the Council members. Take a moment to watch.

posts.title: Sarah Jessica Parker: What Would New York Be Without Libraries?
posts.text: As Carrie Bradshaw might, I couldn’t help but wonder: Can New York City survive without strong public libraries?

posts.title: Jennifer Egan: Writers Need Libraries—Just Like All New Yorkers
posts.text: Join me in signing a letter urging City leaders to support the vital resources that only New York's public libraries provide: free access to millions of books, research materials, and more, for all New Yorkers—novelists, scholars, and book lovers alike.

posts.title: NYPL Bookmobile to Hit the Streets
posts.text: The new NYPL Bookmobile will serve patrons across the Bronx, Manhattan, and Staten Island starting this summer.

posts.title: Angela Yee Speaks Out on Library Workers Day: Librarians Changed My Life
posts.text: Librarians changed my life. Growing up in Brooklyn, library workers guided me toward the books I didn't yet know I needed to read. I learned about womanhood from Judy Blume's Are You There God, It's Me Margaret and the atrocities of racism in Maya Angelou's I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings.

posts.title: Kenny Washington Makes Headlines with L.A. Rams as First Black NFL Player
posts.text: When offered a contract to play for the Los Angeles Rams, Kenny Washington became the first African American player in the modern era NFL.

posts.title: Election 2018: Get Informed and Vote
posts.text: Get ready to vote.

posts.title: Special Edition Knowledge Is Power Library Card Available at NYPL for a Limited Time
posts.text: Do you believe Knowledge Is Power? Show the world with your library card.

posts.title: Maira Kalman's Original Paintings for The Elements of Style Come to NYPL and the Jewish Museum
posts.text: The Jewish Museum and The New York Public Library have jointly acquired the complete series of 57 gouaches on paper created by designer, author, illustrator, and artist Maira Kalman for the 2005 edition of The Elements of Style.

posts.title: Celebrating the Life & Legacy of Anna Atkins
posts.text: This season, The New York Public Library is drawing from its collections—and ideas that continue to inspire artists today—to present two companion exhibitions celebrating the life and legacy of one of photography’s earliest pioneers.

posts.title: Insta Novels: Bringing Classic Literature to Instagram Stories
posts.text: Introducing Insta Novels, a reimagining of Instagram Stories to provide a new platform for iconic stories.

posts.title: New Book Highlights Questions and Answers from the Library Archives
posts.text: The New York Public Library is excited to share that we have teamed up with Macmillan Publishing Group for an ongoing partnership to create and publish a variety of books inspired by the Library and its collections.

posts.title: Jason Reynolds: Protect the Precious Resource That Is the Library
posts.text: When kids say they don't like to read, they’re not actually telling the truth. What they're really saying is that they don't like reading boring books. They haven't yet found the book that will make them fall in love with reading.

posts.title: Toni Morrison: Tell City Leaders to Invest in Libraries
posts.text: "My second job as a teenager was shelving books at the only library in Lorain, Ohio. Every shift started with a tall stack of returned books—fiction, history, drama, poetry, everything. It didn't pay much, but it was magical. Then I got fired." -Toni Morrison

posts.title: Peace, Love, and Revolution at the Library
posts.text: The spirit of the 60s never truly left. And this season, it's front and center at the Library—and across the city—with era-inspired programs, special guests, exhibitions, and more.

posts.title: What Public Libraries Will Lose Without Net Neutrality
posts.text: In an interview posted today on The Verge, NYPL president Tony Marx and associate director of information policy Greg Cram lay out the impact of today’s vote on net neutrality.

posts.title: Summer Reading 2019 | Teen Book Lists
posts.text: Check out the Summer Reading book lists for middle- and high-school age teens.

posts.title: Summer Reading 2019 | Grades K–5 Book Lists
posts.text: Check out the Summer Reading book lists for grade-school kids.

posts.title: Summer Reading 2019 | Early Literacy Book Lists
posts.text: Discover these Summer Reading picks for babies, toddlers, and pre-K kids.

posts.title: Summer Reading 2018 | Teen Book List
posts.text: Check out the Summer Reading book list for middle- and high-school age teens.

posts.title: Summer Reading 2018 | Grades K–5 Book List
posts.text: Check out the Summer Reading book list for kids from kindergarten to grade five.

posts.title: Summer Reading 2018 | Early Literacy Book List
posts.text: Check out the Summer Reading book list for babies, toddlers & pre-K.

posts.title: NYPL's Marianne Moore: Writing Her Way Onto the Shelves
posts.text: In the 1920s, Moore worked as a part-time clerk at the Hudson Park Branch of The New York Public Library, which some critics have linked to the exacting and cataloguing character of her writing.

posts.title: KidsLIVE! Summer 2021 Recap
posts.text: Discover all of the KidsLIVE! programs presented during this summer and find further resources including links to check out books, read-alikes, activities to do at home, and more.

posts.title: Announcing Our Summer Writing Contest 2021 Winners!
posts.text: Find out who won this year's Summer Writing Contest in three different age categories, and read about their ingenious ideas for helping their communities.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Sonia Manzano
posts.text: In addition to playing beloved character Maria on 'Sesame Street,' Marzano is also the author of several children's books.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Misty Copeland and Denene Millner
posts.text: In this program, Copeland and Millner talk about their own books as well as answer librarians' questions about their inspirations and writing processes.

posts.title: KidsLIVE! Blogs: An Author Talk with C.G. Esperanza
posts.text: Author-illustrator C.G. Esperanza's latest work is the picture book 'Boogie Boogie Y'All.'

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with George O'Connor
posts.text: George O'Connor is an author, illustrator, and cartoonist. He's currently working on a 12-book series graphic novel series about the Greek gods.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Matthew Burgess
posts.text: Burgess is the author of 'Drawing on Walls: A Story of Keith Haring,' 'Make Meatballs Sing: The Life and Art of Sister Corita Kent,' Enormous Smallness: A Story of E.E. Cummings' and more.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Saadia Faruqi
posts.text: Saadia Faruqi is a Pakistani American author, essayist, and interfaith activist. She writes the children’s early reader series 'Yasmin' and other books for children as well as middle grade novels.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Mike Curato
posts.text: Enjoy this author talk with Mike Curato, the author-illustrator behind Little Elliot, Big City and many more!

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Tony Medina
posts.text: In this program we were joined by Tony Medina, author of several highly acclaimed poetry books for children, including 'Love to Langston' and 'DeShawn Days'. He presented his latest book 'Thirteen Ways of Looking At A Black Boy' and participated in a Q&A With NYPL librarians.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Mahogany L. Browne
posts.text: The author of 'Chlorine Sky' presented about her book and joined NYPL librarians for a Q&A to discuss her inspirations and what it’s like to be an author.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Ellen Hagan
posts.text: In this program, Hagan, author of the novel in verse 'Reckless, Glorious, Girl', read from the book and then participated in a Q&A with NYPL librarians to discuss her inspirations and what it’s like to be an author.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Ibi Zoboi
posts.text: The author of 'My Life As An Ice Cream Sandwich' joined NYPL librarians to discuss her work and her inspirations. Below, you can watch the program, explore her books in our catalog, and find at-home activities to do with your kids.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: Spring 2021 Recap
posts.text: If you missed any of our KidsLIVE author talks this season, you can find them all gathered here to watch.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Jude Isabella
posts.text: Listen to Jude’s talk about her book, "Bringing Back the Wolves," during a Q&A with NYPL librarians where she discusses her inspirations and what it's like to be an author.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Carole Lindstrom
posts.text: Lindstrom, author of the picture book "We Are Water Protectors," shared with us her inspirations for writing the book and the importance of protecting our planet.

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with James Bird
posts.text: "I wrote 'The Brave' for anyone who grew up being labeled different, weird, or was told they have learning disabilities. I want them to know that we are all unique and so we all learn differently...If we were all the same, life would be so boring."

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Thao Lam
posts.text: We visited with author and illustrator Thao Lam to talk about the story behind her book 'The Paper Boat: A Refugee Story' and get a sneak peek of her new book 'Thao'. Watch now!

posts.title: KidsLIVE!: An Author Talk with Linda Sue Park
posts.text: She joined NYPL librarians to talk about her book 'Prairie Lotus' as well as upcoming writing projects and what it's like to be an author. Watch now!

posts.title: NYPL's Mini Music Series for Kids
posts.text: Join The New York Public Library for our first Mini Music Series for Kids, running December 14–18, 2020.

posts.title: 75 lecturas imprescindibles sobre la salud mental
posts.text: ¿Sabías que leer puede ayudar a mejorar la salud mental? ¡Explora la siguiente selección de 75 libros sobre salud mental! Estas recomendaciones de lectura cubren de todo, desde la práctica del cuidado personal o autocuidado hasta la comprensión de las enfermedades mentales.

posts.title: 39 Mental Wellness Must Reads
posts.text: Did you know reading can boost mental health? Explore these powerful mental health reads that cover everything from practicing self-care to understanding mental illness.

posts.title: November is National Novel Writing Month: Register Now for Workshops with New York Writers Workshop
posts.text: The New York Public Library is delighted to join forces with New York Writers Workshop (NYWW) to present a series of writing workshops for this year's National Novel Writing Month (NaNoWriMo). You can now register to join writers Christina Chiu, Laura Geringer Bass, Charles Salzberg, Ravi Shankar, and Laura Zinn Fromm.

posts.title: NYPL Researcher Spotlight: Tatjana Bergelt
posts.text: Her advice to potential researchers: "Do not be scared off by the magnificence of this institution...a library is only as important as its potential readers."

posts.title: NYPL Researcher Spotlight: Flavie Épié
posts.text: She is a PhD candidate in English studies at Université Bordeaux-Montaigne and Universiteit Antwerpen. Her research addresses collaborative translation processes, with a specific focus on the French translations of James Joyce’s Ulysses.

posts.title: Materiality in Eighteenth-Century Epistolary Fiction
posts.text: Pichaya Damrongpiwat's time in the Berg Collection changed the direction of her research.

posts.title: Transport Your Mind: Books About Bookmobiles and Mobile Libraries
posts.text: Bookmobiles are one of the creative ways libraries and bookstores bring reading materials and valuable resources to their communities.

posts.title: What Zeyn Joukhadar Is Reading
posts.text: Recommended reading selected by author Zeyn Joukhadar.

posts.title: What Erin Geiger Smith Is Reading
posts.text: Recommended reading selected by journalist and author Erin Geiger Smith.

posts.title: What Lauren Wilkinson Is Reading
posts.text: Recommended reading list from the author of American Spy.

posts.title: Meet Our 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award Finalists: Bryan Washington, Lot
posts.text: Interview and recommended reading list from one of the 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award finalists.

posts.title: Meet Our 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award Finalists: Xuan Juliana Wang, Home Remedies
posts.text: Interview and recommended reading list from one of the 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award finalists.

posts.title: Meet Our 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award Finalists: Kiley Reid, Such a Fun Age
posts.text: Interview and recommended reading list from one of the 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award finalists.

posts.title: Meet Our 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award Finalists: Julia Phillips, Disappearing Earth
posts.text: Interview and recommended reading list from one of the 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award finalists.

posts.title: What Caroline Weber Is Reading
posts.text: Historical fiction recommendations from professor and author of 'Proust's Duchess'.

posts.title: Meet the 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award Finalists: Steph Cha, Your House Will Pay
posts.text: Interview and recommended reading list from one of the 2020 Young Lions Fiction Award finalists.

posts.title: What Elliot Ackerman Is Reading
posts.text: Recommendations from award-winning author Elliot Ackerman.

posts.title: Journey Back in Time: What Fiona Davis Is Reading & Library Trivia
posts.text: Recommendations from the best-selling author of historical novels set in iconic New York City buildings such as 'The Lions of Fifth Avenue'.

posts.title: What Geraldine Brooks Is Reading
posts.text: Recommendations from the author of award-winning novels and New York Times bestsellers 'Caleb's Crossing' and 'People of the Book'.

posts.title: What Paul Yoon Is Reading
posts.text: The Young Lions Fiction award winner shares his reading recommendations.

posts.title: What Tayari Jones Is Reading
posts.text: Six composite novels perfect for short attention span reading.

posts.title: NYPL Remembers Eric Carle
posts.text: We are deeply saddened to lose innovative and beloved children's author, illustrator, and designer Eric Carle, whose colorful, interactive books have enchanted and delighted children for decades.

posts.title: NYPL Researcher Spotlight: Elizabeth Kerri Mahon
posts.text: Author, actress and history geek, Mahon's latest book project required access to primary sources which she was able to access at NYPL even during the pandemic.

posts.title: Researcher Spotlight: Andrew Silverstein
posts.text: "I can’t wait to get back in the reading room. However, this past year I’ve been amazed to learn how much I can research through NYPL remotely."

posts.title: First Saturdays Library Cardholder Discount at the Library Shop
posts.text: Mark your calendars now! Show your New York Public Library card to receive 10% off your purchase at the Library Shop on the first Saturday of every month.
